case_vignette: A 11-year-old male with past medical history of medulloblastoma is brought to dermatology clinic for evaluation of multiple "moles" on the face, neck, arms and legs. Patient's mother reports developing similar lesions when she was younger and a history of ovarian fibromas.  Examination reveals multiple thin brown pedunculated papules on the cheeks, neck, and upper chest and back. Focal atrophic ovoid papules are appreciated on the palms bilaterally.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a bunch of "moles" on my face, neck, arms, and legs.
Can you describe the appearance of these moles?
They are thin, brown, and have a small stalk, especially the ones on my cheeks, neck, upper chest, and back.
Have you noticed any changes in the size, shape, color, or texture of these moles recently?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in them.
Have you had any family members with skin cancer or any other skin conditions?
Yes, my mother had similar spots when she was younger and also had ovarian fibromas.
Have you been exposed to any harmful UV radiation or chemicals that could have caused skin damage?
I'm just a kid; I don't know about all that.
Have you had any other skin issues or concerns in the past?
No new issues, just the "moles" that I mentioned before.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic Keratosis

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got these little brown skin tags on my face, neck, and upper chest and back, and some flat, shrunken patches on both of my hands.
Have you noticed any changes in the appearance of these skin tags and patches over time?
My mom mentioned that they look similar to what she had when she was younger.
Have you noticed any itching or discomfort in the areas where these skin tags and patches are located?
No, I haven't felt any itching or discomfort.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin's texture or color in these areas?
The skin tags are thin and brown, and the patches on my hands are flat and a bit shrunken.

No, I haven't noticed any changes in my weight or overall health.

No, there haven't been any recent changes in my diet or lifestyle.

No, my stress levels and sleep patterns have been pretty much the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your family history of skin conditions?

Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic Keratosis with Ovarian Fibromas.
